{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': 'pkjmfptk7w', 'content': 'A liquid crystalline layer in the nematic or smectic phase has a director, which is the vector along which the long axis of the molecules are parallel. When unpolarized light passes through a layer of liquid crystals in such an aligned phase, the light exiting the polarizer has one of two possible polarizations. Is the light polarized parallel to or perpendicular to the director of the liquid crystal layer? Hint: the polarization follows the same convention as a wire-grid polarizer.'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': 'pkjmfptk7w', 'content': 'What is the bulk heterojunction and why is it advantageous to devices which have a flat interface between the electron-donating and electron-accepting semiconductors? Note that this problem applies to excitonic solar cells only; silicon solar cells are not believed to benefit from this type of interpenetration between the phases.'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': 'pkjmfptk7w', 'content': 'You are hired into a team of engineers at a new startup company making solar cells based on semiconductor nanocrystals. Your company has patents on two types of nanocrystals which, when cast from solution, one has a valence band energy of --5.9 eV and a band gap of 1.6 eV, and the other has a valence band energy of --4.8 eV and a bandgap of 1.6 eV. The exciton diffusion length in both materials is 10 nm and the absorption length at visible wavelengths is 100 nm. These nanocrystals can be processed from solution in hexane. You also have access to the local university nanofabrication facility---including a class-100 cleanroom---which has a suite of tools for evaporation of metals and oxides, and can perform e-beam lithography, photolithography, and molding. Design a solar cell based on the two types of semiconductor nanocrystals. Use as many diagrams as you wish.'}
